title: 114_hr3442
content: The Act titled "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" requires the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress before reaching the debt limit. The "Debt Management and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2015" mandates the Secretary of the Treasury to report to Congress 60-21 days before the public debt reaches the specified limit. The report must include historical debt levels. The Secretary must submit a report on the state of the public debt, including historical levels, current amount, future projections, Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, and measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised. The Secretary must report on the state of public debt, including historical levels, current amount, future projections, Federal revenue levels, drivers of future debt, measures to fund obligations if the debt limit is not raised, and any reduction measures to fund government obligations. Additionally, the report may include a recommendation for a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation. The Secretary may recommend a balanced budget amendment to control future debt accumulation, detailing proposals to reduce public debt in the short, medium, and long term, the impact of an increased debt limit on Government spending and the dollar's position as the international reserve currency, and projections of fiscal health. The curr_chunk discusses projections of fiscal health and sustainability of major direct-spending entitlement programs, as well as the President's plan to disclose reduction measures when the US Government's debt reaches the statutory limit. The curr_chunk provides details on reduction measures used by the Secretary to avoid defaulting on Government obligations, including the total dollar amounts used and estimated available. It also includes the date when all reduction measures will be exhausted, leading to Government default. The Secretary will exhaust reduction measures to avoid default on Government obligations, including projected extraordinary measures and their duration. The Administration's capability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt is questioned if the debt limit is not raised. The Administration's ability to pay only principal and interest on the national debt is questioned if the debt limit is reached. A progress report on implementing the President's proposals will be submitted if a Secretary has appeared at least once. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide public access to information on the Department of the Treasury's website, including debt reports, detailed explanations, progress reports, and other relevant information related to the statutory debt limit and Government debt. The Secretary of the Treasury must provide public access to information on the Department of the Treasury's website, including debt reports, detailed explanations, progress reports, and other relevant information related to the statutory debt limit and Government debt. Reduction measures defined in this section include directing or approving debt issuance by the Federal Financing Bank, suspending investments in the Government Securities Investment Fund, and suspending investments in the stabilization fund. The Secretary of the Treasury can take various measures to reduce debt, including suspending investments in different funds, selling assets before maturity, and other appropriate actions as determined by the Secretary. The House of Representatives passed a report on reaching the debt limit on February 11, 2016, attested by Karen L. Haas, Clerk.
